unit_learning_outcomes.description: Assess manuscripts for readability, and justify measures for their enhancement
Identify a range of grammatical categories and their effectiveness in different types of text.
Critique alternative linguistic styles and modes of communication
Define the needs of particular audiences and make appropriate language choices for them

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Investigation into changes in current current language use, to be brought to particular relevant weekly discussions (e.g. nominalisation, current grammatical issues)
Engagement in online discussion board based around weekly topic
Reading of online notes and additional readings related to weekly lectures.

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to GradCertEditElecPub or MCrWrit or GradDipCrWrit or MAccComm or MEd

assessments.description: Identification of nominalisation and appropriateness to discourse; application of editorial skills to correct unnecessary nominalisation.
Application of punctuation to texts, and discussion of effect of punctuation on different types of text.
Creation of different types of text for promotion/presentation of a scholarly journal, and justification of approach.
Analysis of features of electronic communication

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit focuses on language, including variation in grammar, usage and punctuation, and linguistic approaches to writing style, discourse development and readability. It examines the features of different text types, spoken and written, as well as those evolving on the internet. It discusses communicative approaches to writing, including plain English for mediating complex content, and promotional writing for advertising purposes. It includes modules on editing Aboriginal English, and on academic writing and editing, especially theses and journal articles.
